did.unittitle: Brooklyn Film and Arts Festival Collection
did.abstract: Five films that were presented at the 2011 Brooklyn Film & Arts Festival.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: From the Brooklyn Film and Arts Festival website ( www.filmbrooklyn.org): The main focus of the Brooklyn Film and Arts Festival programs is Brooklyn, its history, communities, neighborhoods, cultures, peoples, social dynamics, arts, and related Brooklyn topics. The Brooklyn Film & Arts Festival aims to present a series of cultural events that convey the quintessentially unique perspective of Brooklyn residents about their own neighborhoods and their views about Brooklyn at large. The films in this collection were shown at the 2011 Brooklyn Film & Arts Festival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of five films on five DVDs. The earliest is from 1969, and the rest were filmed from 2006 – 2009.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is located in the Brooklyn Collection at the Central Branch at Grand Army Plaza. The collection may only be used in the library and is not available through interlibrary loan. Requests to view the collection must be made at least 48 hours in advance of visit.

userestrict.head: Use
userestrict.p: While many items in the Brooklyn Collection are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Donated by Aziz Rahman, curator of the Brooklyn Film & Arts Festival, in December 2011.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The DVDs are arranged in one box alphabetically by title.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The researcher should cite the individual film as well as citing the collection as the Brooklyn Film & Arts Festival Collection, Brooklyn Public Library – Brooklyn Collection.

odd.head: General
odd.p: A young Brooklyn filmmaker takes the audience on a lyrical tour of his cherished Brooklyn world from Park Slope to Coney Island. Through the pensively wrought sights we are witness to the soulful richness of Brooklyn's landscape. Directed and filmed by teenage filmmaker Derek Garcia.

odd.head: General
odd.p: A filmmaker returns to her old neighborhood to examine the changes underway in Bushwick and to convey the experiences of those residents who survived the crime waves and community erosion of the 1980s and 90s. This documentary examines the roots of the drastic changes in Bushwick and the lessons learned by community members who survived the most turbulent era of Bushwick. Directed and produced by Stefanie Joshua. Distributed by the filmmaker through Msjosh Productions, LLC.

odd.head: General
odd.p: A virtual visual time-capsule captures the Brunjes family strolling through lively Coney Island in 1969. From a child's eye view of Coney Island rides and hoopla which brings home the flavor of Brooklyn's timeless seaside attractions.

did.unittitle: Little Caughnawaga: to Brooklyn and back

odd.head: General
odd.p: The personal story of Mohawk filmmaker Reaghan Tarbell as she explores her Brooklyn roots. The film tells the story of the legendary Mohawk steelworkers and their families who travelled to North Gowanus in Brooklyn from the Kahnawake reserve in Canada to build the skyscrapers of New York City. Reaghan Tarbell interweaves family interviews and archival footage to convey the long-standing roots of the Mohawk people in Brooklyn. Written and directed by Reaghan Tarbell and produced by Paul M. Rickard. George Hargrave served as Executive Producer for the program. US/Canadian distributors: (Visionmaker/NFB)

odd.head: General
odd.p: Up on the Roof follows several devoted pigeon breeders in one predominantly Latino section of Brooklyn through the rigors and rewards of a quintessential New York tradition. All along the waterfront, and throughout blue collar Brooklyn, pigeon fancying has been an active pastime for centuries, handed down from one group of residents to the next, and Williamsburg has long been the center of the action. But as with so many once blighted and now hip districts throughout the world, Brooklyn—and Williamsburg in particular—is being scrubbed of its old world character to make way for a new urbanism. This considers what we lose in the process of urban renewal and treats the audience like an insider in an unseen and in many ways vanishing world. Produced, directed and filmed by J.L. Aronson. Distributed by Creative Arson Productions.
